tr.td:
Data available ‘off the shelf’ and non-proprietary.
No visit to the location needed unless using reflectors
Covers large areas at great accuracy and detail.
Frequent repeatability
Easy to combine with production / injection data.

Very sensitive, shows slope direction of ground surface. ‘Pulsing’ of the reservoir can be observed using continuous reading near-surface tiltmeters.
Integrating and fitting with surface production and injection data to make decisions can be challenging.

Excellent but seldom used because downhole tiltmeters are rare.
Integrating the data and interpreting it is very time-consuming. Using it to make impactful decisions is tough.
Very accurate but generally few points per unit area. Time- and effort-intensive.

Traditional methods, widely used:
¿ Open-hole logging and RFT surveys in new wells.
¿ Regular cased-hole logging and DTS/DAS in dedicated observation wells.
¿ Radioactive bullets (Dorndorf, 2006)
¿ Zonal injection surveys in injection wells Great but generally sparse coverage within a field.
Only applied to very small areas because of cost.

Best reserved for observing microseisms caused by hydraulic fracturing and microfracturing.
Does not observe fluid flow through rock matrix.
Useful offshore where few other methods are feasible. Onshore, thick low velocity layers above the water table soak up the reflected signal.
Producers have gravel-pack / slotted liner completions
Initial primary gas expansion followed by water or steam injection for pressure maintenance and drive. Producers are hydraulically fractured (Harris, 2016)

tr.th: Daily Production Rates Daily Injection and Disposal Rates

tr.td:
1,7E5 BO, 0.3 MMCFG,
25,2E5 BW (E3% watercut)
11,168 BW (Steam as CWE) inj.
8,682 BW disposed

2,001 BO, 1.1 MMCFG,
1E,54E BW (E1% watercut)
22,541 BW inj.
Small changes in elevation that tend to cover tens to hundreds of acres

Imbalance in the reservoir(s) between fluid volumes produced and fluid volumes injected. The deeper the reservoir, the more muted the surface response. However, we have never seen a field without a dynamic surface deformation signal that is easily detectable with the new high-grade InSAR products.
Small-scale, high amplitude events covering 5 to 50 acres (we call them ‘surface blisters’)
Uplift due to fluids that have moved close enough to the surface to raise the surface of the ground. These may be precursors to surface expressions and have HSE consequences.

Data available ‘off the shelf’ and non-proprietary.
No visit to the location needed unless using reflectors Covers large areas at great accuracy and detail.
Frequent repeatability Easy to combine with production / injection data.

Very sensitive, shows slope direction of ground surface.
‘Pulsing’ of the reservoir can be observed using continuous reading near-surface tiltmeters.
Integrating and fitting with surface production and injection data to make decisions can be challenging.

Excellent but seldom used because downhole tiltmeters are rare. Integrating the data and interpreting it is very time-consuming.
Using it to make impactful decisions is tough.

Very accurate but few points per unit area.
Time-and effort-intensive.

Traditional methods, widely used:
¿ Open-hole logging and RFT surveys in new wells.
¿ Regular cased-hole logging and DTS/DAS in dedicated observation wells.
¿ Radioactive bullets (Dorndorf, 2006)
¿ Zonal injection surveys in injection wells Great but generally sparse coverage within a field.
Only applied to very small areas because of cost.

Best reserved for observing microseisms caused by hydraulic fracturing and microfracturing.
Does not observe fluid flow through rock matrix.

Useful offshore where few other methods are feasible.
Onshore, thick low velocity layers above the water table often soak up the reflected signal.
